itemDescription: Irish recipient of the Victoria Cross

wikipedia_page.main:
Michael Murphy VC (c. 1837, Cahir, County Tipperary, Ireland – 4 April 1893, Darlington, County Durham, England) was an Irish recipient of the Victoria Cross (VC), the highest award for gallantry in the face of the enemy that can be awarded to British and other Commonwealth forces.
Murphy was born c. 1837 in Cahir, County Tipperary, to Michael Murphy, a local blacksmith, and his (unknown) wife. He had at least two younger sisters, named Mary and Julia Mary. Little is known about his early life until 1855, when he started his army career.

response: *Michael Murphy (1831–93), awarded Victoria Cross, later forfeited
*Private (Farrier) Michael Murphy VC (forfeited). Military Train. 15 April 1858.
Michael Murphy, Mick Murphy, or Mike Murphy may refer to:
* Michael Murphy (actor) (born 1938), American actor
* Michael Murphy (singer) (born 1986), New Zealand Idol runner up
* Michael Murphy (sculptor) (born 1975), American artist
* Michael Murphy (Australian footballer) (born 1965), VFL/AFL player
* Michael Murphy (Gaelic footballer) (born 1989), Donegal and Glenswilly sportsman
* Michael Murphy (cricketer) (1854–1890), Australian cricketer
* Michael Murphy (diver) (born 1973), Australian Olympic diver
* Michael Murphy (Templederry hurler) (born 1959), Irish hurler
* Michael Murphy, head women's basketball coach for Troy University
* Michael Murphy (Indiana politician) (born 1957), member of the Indiana House of Representatives
* Michael Murphy (Irish politician) (1919–2000), Irish Labour Party politician
* Michael Murphy (VC) (c. 1837–1893), Irish recipient of the Victoria Cross
* Michael Murphy, fictional character in the TV series The Leftovers
* Michael Murphy, main protagonist of Babylon Rising
* Michael Murphy (author) (born 1930), American Integral Movement author and co-founder of the Esalen Institute
* Michael Murphy (priest) (c. 1767–1798), co-leader of the Irish Rebellion of 1798
* Michael Murphy (bishop) 20th Century Irish Roman Catholic bishop
* Michael Murphy (academic), former President of University College Cork
* Michael Murphy (New Zealand magistrate) (1806–1852), New Zealander clerk, police magistrate, and subsheriff
* Michael Murphy (journalist) (born 1948/49), news reader with RTÉ
* Michael Murphy (pilot) (born 1816), 19th-century American New York Sandy Hook maritime pilot

response: |||align="center"|1858||Indian Rebellion of 1857||01717th Lancers||Azumgurh, India||align="center"|Michael Murphy was one eight VC recipients whose award was forfeited. Although King George V in 1920 expressed the view that the VC should not be forfeited, the medals of Murphy and the other seven were not restored. List of Recipients of the Victoria Cross, The War Office (MS3), January 1953, note, page 7.

link_mentions.page: List of revocations of appointments to orders and awarded decorations and medals of the United Kingdom
response: *1872: Michael Murphy (awarded 1859), following his conviction for theft.

Morley's regiment was deployed to India in 1857. On 15 April 1858, Morley was in position at Nathupur, near Azimgurh, in north-east India. During the fighting, Morley and Farrier Michael Murphy rushed to the aid of Lieutenant Hamilton, adjutant of the 3rd Sikh Cavalry, who had been unhorsed. Hamilton died from his injuries the next evening.
